Key Match Events: Bradley Beal's first game off the bench helped the Suns flip the switch, igniting Phoenix back into the ball game.
Beal became the primary scorer of the second unit and provided the counter-offensive runs that steered the Suns to a massive third-quarter surge, outscoring the 76ers, 36-27.
Durant started to operate in the perimeter and capitalized on every switch mismatch to get more advantageous plays.
Booker orchestrated the Phoenix offense, locating the open wing shooters to end up with a team-high 10 assists.

Philadelphia threatened to get back midway through the fourth as Paul George and Tyrese Maxey hit some timely buckets, but Durant scored back-to-back fade-away jumpers capped off by a reverse layup to balloon their cushion back to double digits.
Ryan Dunn knocked down a barrage of three-pointers and was also pesky on the defensive end as he took on the challenge of guarding George in the game.
Pre-Game Insights: Two days before the game, the Phoenix coaching staff announced that Bradley Beal would be relegated to the sideline and would not start together with Kevin Durant and Devin Booker.
